item.title: Ukrainian drones destroy Russian patrol ships, defense ministry says
item.description: Raptor patrol boats, which can carry up to 23 personnel, are usually equipped with machine guns and used in reconnaissance or landing operations.

item.title: Israel demands apology after Russian official says Hitler had Jewish roots
item.description: "This is an unforgivable and outrageous statement and a terrible historic mistake and we expect an apology," Israel's foreign minister said.

item.title: Parents of hostage Austin Tice, who was abducted in Syria, meet with Biden
item.description: President Biden said at the White House Correspondents Dinner that he'd like to meet with them.

item.title: Nearly 100 out of Mariupol steelworks plant, but soldiers behind battle Russian advance
item.description: CBS News senior foreign correspondent Charlie D'Agata reports from near the front lines in eastern Ukraine, where evidence shows Russian forces increasing in number and preparing for a stronger advance.

item.title: Biden requests additional $33 billion in aid to Ukraine as Congress disagrees on COVID funding
item.description: President Biden is requesting an additional $33 billion in military, economic and humanitarian aid for Ukraine and its allies. CBS News congressional correspondent Nikole Killion reports from Capitol Hill.

item.title: Dazed survivors emerge after weeks hiding under Ukraine steel plant
item.description: Ceasefire enables dozens to escape a makeshift bomb shelter in Mariupol, but elsewhere Ukraine's embattled forces are desperate for more U.S. weapons.

item.title: Angelina Jolie makes surprise visit to Ukraine
item.description: Angelina Jolie met children who were injured in a Russian missile attack on a railway station last month, Lviv's regional governor said.

item.title: Australian could be jailed for life for pushing gay American off cliff
item.description: The man admitted to pushing Scott Johnson off a Sydney clifftop in what prosecutors now call a hate crime, but police initially dismissed as a suicide.

item.title: COVID-free Shanghai residents forced into distant quarantine centers
item.description: As China's biggest cities grapple with coronavirus outbreaks, some say they've been given "no choice" by authorities trying desperately to stamp out all cases.

item.title: Putin's war creates schism in Russian Orthodox Church
item.description: The Moscow-based church's leadership has framed Russia's invasion of Ukraine in holy terms - as a defense of conservative values against a morally-corrupt West. Now, the war has prompted dissent within the Orthodox Christian faith.

item.title: North Korea's Kim threatens to use nukes preemptively "if necessary"
item.description: Kim Jong Un expressed "firm will" to continue developing his nuclear-armed military, North Korea's official news agency said.

item.title: Mexico captures powerful cartel leader, accused in 3 doctors' murders
item.description: Francisco Javier Rodriguez Hernandez is also accused of controlling several laboratories for the production of synthetic drugs.

item.title: CBS News exclusive: Newly released video shows 9/11 hijacker with Saudi intelligence operative
item.description: Newly released evidence — including video of a February 2000 house party in San Diego, California — shows a Saudi intelligence operative knew some of the hijackers who attacked the Pentagon on September 11, 2001. CBS News' senior investigative correspondent Catherine Herridge reports from Washington, D.C.

item.title: Pelosi meets with Zelenskyy in Kyiv, vowing U.S. support for Ukraine
item.description: Pelosi and a half-dozen U.S. lawmakers met for three hours with Zelenskyy and his top aides to get a first-hand assessment of the war effort to date.

item.title: Evacuations of civilians hiding in steel plant in Mariupol finally underway
item.description: A long-awaited effort to evacuate people from a steel plant in the Ukrainian city of Mariupol has begun, officials said Sunday.

item.title: 4/30: CBS Saturday Morning
item.description: Destructive tornado hits parts of Kansas; The history of the Forecourt of the Stars, the TCL Chinese Theatre.

item.title: The Switchblade "kamikaze" drone
item.description: A one-time-use unmanned aerial vehicle, the Switchblade drone is a powerful weapon that can dive bomb its targets, such as tanks and artillery nests, at a range of up to 30 miles. So far, 700 Switchblades – large and small – have been supplied to Ukraine for use against Russian forces. CBS News national security correspondent David Martin talks with the CEO of Switchblade manufacturer Aerovironment, Wahid Nawabi, who as a child in Afghanistan saw the effects of an invading Russian army – and the power of innovative defense technology.

item.title: Fighting intensifies in eastern Ukraine as civilians flee
item.description: CBS News senior foreign correspondent Charlie D'Agata reports from eastern Ukraine, where one battalion commander said he has yet to receive any heavy weapons promised by the U.S.

item.title: Russian Orthodox leader's support of war divides church
item.description: Patriarch Kirill, head of the Russian Orthodox Church, has framed President Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine in holy terms – as a defense of conservative values against a morally corrupt West. Now, the war has prompted dissent within the Orthodox Christian faith. Correspondent Seth Doane talks with Orthodox adherents who say the message from their church's Moscow leadership and the Kremlin's war propaganda are one and the same.

item.title: Samantha Power urges Congress to address "desperate need" for Ukraine aid
item.description: President Biden has requested an additional $33 billion in aid for Ukraine from Congress.

item.title: Transcript: USAID chief Samantha Power on "Face the Nation"
item.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Samantha Power, the administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development, that aired Sunday, May 1, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

item.title: Transcript: Sen. Tim Kaine on "Face the Nation"
item.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia that aired Sunday, May 1, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

item.title: Switchblade drone: How the "kamikaze" anti-tank weapon works
item.description: The one-time use unmanned aerial vehicle is a powerful weapon that can dive bomb its targets, such as tanks and artillery nests, at a range of up to 30 miles – and is being supplied by the hundreds to Ukraine for use against Russian forces.

item.title: Russia continues threats to use nuclear weapons
item.description: The Chernobyl disaster happened 36 years ago, but now Ukraine is faced with a new nuclear threat. Russian forces have fired artillery near nuclear power plants and the Kremlin continues to threaten to use nuclear weapons in its offensive against Ukraine. Chris Livesay has more.

item.title: Ukraine's forces fight to hold off Russian offensive
item.description: The Kremlin is seeking to capture Ukraine's industrial Donbas region and Western military analysts said Moscow's offensive was going much slower than planned.

item.title: The history of the Forecourt of the Stars, the TCL Chinese Theatre
item.description: The TCL Chinese Theatre is considered one of the world's most iconic cinemas. Nearby, the Forecourt of the Stars has become a beloved time capsule where hundreds of stars have left a unique token of themselves behind. Marci Gonzalez has more.

item.title: U.K. politician Neil Parish admits to watching porn in Parliament
item.description: He offered a "total full apology" for his actions, which he described as a "moment of madness."

item.title: Defense official: Russian offensive is moving slower than expected
item.description: Russian forces are meeting fierce resistance as they try to advance in Ukraine's south and east. Chris Livesay has the latest.

item.title: The rise of fashion designer Awet Woldegebriel
item.description: From his father's tailor shop in Ethiopia to his own featured clothing line at one of America's premier department stores, Awet Woldegebriel has truly been living the American dream. Michelle Miller has more on his journey.

item.title: Family remembers U.S. Marine veteran killed fighting in Ukraine
item.description: President Biden is asking Congress to approve $33 billion in Ukraine aid to ramp up pressure on Russia. This comes as a family mourns the loss of a U.S. Marine veteran who was killed fighting alongside Ukrainian forces. Debra Alfarone has more.

item.title: Russians are several days behind their goal in Ukraine, Pentagon assesses
item.description: A senior defense official said Friday that Russia expected to be farther along in encircling Ukrainian forces in the east.

item.title: U.S. Marine veteran killed fighting in Ukraine
item.description: Willy Joseph Cancel, a U.S. Marine veteran, was killed fighting alongside Ukrainian forces in the war with Russia, his family said. His widow told CBS News "he just wanted to help people." Charlie D'Agata reports.

item.title: World Food Programme tackles Ukraine hunger crisis
item.description: The United Nations World Food Programme says nearly half of Ukrainian residents worry about where they'll find their next meal. For ""60 Minutes,"" Scott Pelley traveled to Ukraine with the WFP's David Beasley to follow the organization's efforts to curb the hunger crisis.

item.title: China imposes strict COVID protocols in Beijing
item.description: Almost all of Beijing's 21 million residents had to be tested three times for COVID-19 this week as China continues its zero-COVID policies. Elizabeth Palmer shares the latest.

item.title: American killed fighting alongside Ukraine's forces, family says
item.description: "He wanted to go over because he believed in what Ukraine was fighting for," Willy Joseph Cancel's mother said.

item.title: Zelenskyy denounces Russian attack on Kyiv during U.N. chief's visit
item.description: The Ukrainian president said it was an attempt by Moscow to humiliate the world body. He also said his country's fighters were still holding Russian forces at bay in the south and east.

item.title: British national sentenced to life in prison over deaths of 4 Americans
item.description: The death penalty was not an option under the terms of the agreement that allowed Kotey and another man to be extradited to the U.S.

item.title: Tennis great Boris Becker sentenced to prison for bankruptcy offenses
item.description: The three-time Wimbledon champion will serve 2 1/2 years for transferring large sums of money and hiding assets after bankruptcy.

item.title: Italian court overturns tradition of newborns receiving their father's last name
item.description: The current practice of using the father's last name is "discriminatory and harmful to the identity" of the child, the court said in a statement,

item.title: Family of American killed in Ukraine confirm his death as Russia ignores U.N. calls for peace
item.description: As news emerges of the death of an American volunteer fighter in Ukraine, Kyiv is still cleaning up after Russians shelled the city during U.N. Secretary-General António Guterres' visit. Chris Livesay reports.

item.title: Woman's death shines light on other mysterious murders in Mexico
item.description: Many other notorious cases have gone unsolved — at least in the public's mind — for years or even decades:

item.title: Bipartisan lawmakers receptive to $33 billion Ukraine aid package
item.description: "Time is of the essence," said one top House Republican.

item.title: Russia's invasion of Ukraine sparks nuclear war fears
item.description: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has renewed nuclear war fears, something many Americans haven't thought about since the Cold War. Tony Dokoupil chats with nuclear war experts and visits an old fallout shelter to see how prepared Americans would be in the face of a nuclear threat.

item.title: Gunmen abduct female soldiers vacationing on beach in Mexico
item.description: "They were kidnapped for the simple reason that they belonged to the army," Gen. Vicente Pérez López said.

item.title: Wreckage on Mars captured by NASA's Ingenuity helicopter
item.description: NASA's tiny but mighty helicopter has beamed back incredible images detailing the wreckage from its intense landing on the red planet.

item.title: CBS News poll: 70% of adults worried war in Ukraine could lead to nuclear warfare
item.description: Some fear that a nuclear war could be on the horizon due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Dozens hurt in fresh clashes at key Jerusalem holy site
item.description: Palestinians hurled stones and Israeli police fired rubber-coated bullets at the Al-Aqsa Mosque. In Iran, pro-Palestinian and anti-Israel rallies were held across the country.

item.title: Congress passes bill letting U.S. lend weapons systems to Ukraine
item.description: The bill now goes to President Biden's desk.

item.title: Scientists share how climate change could change daily life
item.description: Experts say we're "running out of time" — and without urgent action, the planet will be radically different.

item.title: Russian missiles strike Kyiv as U.N. chief visits
item.description: Russian missiles hit Kyiv on the same day the head of the United Nations visited Ukraine's capital. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy called the attacks an effort by Russia to "humiliate" the United Nations. Chris Livesay reports.
